perturbation.original_text: 3.2.3. "Gross Revenues" means all revenue from the sale of all services and products and all other income of every kind and nature related to, derived from, or originating from the Franchised Business, including proceeds of any business interruption insurance policies, whether for cash or credit, and regardless of collection in the case of credit; provided, however, that "Gross Revenues" does not include any coupon sales (for which customers do not pay for product), customer refunds, sales taxes or other taxes you collected from customers and actually transmitted to the appropriate taxing authorities.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.2.3. "Gross Revenues" means all revenue from the sale of all services and products related to, derived from, or originating from the Franchised Business.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition explicitly excludes certain items like sales taxes and customer refunds from 'Gross Revenues'. The modified text removes this exclusion, creating ambiguity and a potential contradiction. Other sections still reference 'Gross Revenues' with the expectation that these exclusions apply, but the modified definition no longer supports that assumption. This affects royalty calculations and other financial obligations, making enforcement uncertain.

perturbation.changed_text: 6.19.1. Types and Amounts of Coverage. Throughout the entire Term, you must maintain such types of insurance, in such amounts, as we may require. Such insurance is in addition to any other insurance that may be required by applicable law, your landlord, or otherwise. Policies that we require must be written by an insurance company reasonably satisfactory to us with an A.M. Best rating of "A" or better, and, must name us as an additional insured party.
perturbation.explanation: The original section lists specific types and minimum amounts of insurance coverage the franchisee must maintain. The modified version removes these specifics, stating only that the franchisee must maintain insurance types and amounts 'as we may require'. This omission creates uncertainty and potential contradiction. Other sections may reference the expectation of specific coverage levels, but this section now allows the franchisor to set those levels arbitrarily. If no additional documentation outlines those standards, enforcement becomes difficult.

perturbation.original_text: 17.2. After Termination, Expiration, or Transfer. For two (2) years after the expiration or termination of this Agreement or an approved Transfer to a new franchisee, you may not directly or indirectly own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within three (3) mile radius of the Premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Restaurant then-operating or under construction to operate under the System, except as permitted by any Franchise Agreements that remain in effect between you and us.
perturbation.changed_text: 17.2. After Termination, Expiration, or Transfer. You may not directly or indirectly own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines a specific geographic restriction for competition after termination (two years, three-mile radius). The changed text removes the geographic limitation entirely, implying a global restriction on competition. Other contract clauses assume the geographic restriction in the original text and may become unenforceable due to the omission of the restriction.
